headline: Government Defends Controversial Pay Equity Law Change Amid Heated Debate on Survivor Redress
summary: Parliament was dominated by two highly charged issues today as the Government defended its decision to urgently overhaul pay equity laws, cancelling dozens of claims, while simultaneously facing an emotional urgent debate over its refusal to create a new, independent redress scheme for survivors of abuse in state care. Question Time saw fiery exchanges over the pay equity changes, which the opposition claims were rushed through to save money at the expense of low-paid women. The afternoon was then consumed by a debate where the government's approach to compensating abuse survivors was labelled 'soul destroying' by critics.

topicSummaries.topic: Government Pushes Through Controversial Pay Equity Law Changes
topicSummaries.content: The government faced intense questioning over its decision to repeal and replace parts of the pay equity law under urgency, a move that extinguished 33 active claims affecting an estimated 180,000 workers, many in female-dominated industries. Prime Minister Christopher Luxon defended the action, stating the previous law was "unworkable and unaffordable" and that moving with speed provided certainty. The Opposition and Greens accused the government of avoiding public scrutiny, cutting off pathways to fair pay for low-paid women, and failing to act in good faith on previously agreed backdated settlements.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Chris Hipkins (Leader of the Opposition)
keyExchanges.quote: Why did the Government agree to backdate pay equity settlements as part of a range of collective employment agreement negotiations over the past year despite having already agreed to repeal the law and extinguish those very same pay equity claims they had agreed to backdate, and is that what his Government regards as good faith?

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Christopher Luxon (Prime Minister)
keyExchanges.quote: I am aware of that, but what I am saying to the member is that we have decided to change and fix the pay equity legislation in this country. Labour rushed it through. Labour left a lot of flaws in it. We are fixing it, because it's unworkable and unaffordable.

topicSummaries.topic: Urgent Debate Held on Redress Scheme for Abuse Survivors
topicSummaries.content: Following a request from Labour, the House held an urgent debate on the government's decision not to establish a new, independent redress scheme for survivors of abuse in care, as recommended by the Royal Commission. The government announced it would instead invest $774 million to improve the existing system. Minister Erica Stanford argued this approach would provide certainty and faster payments for survivors, stating a new complex system would be too expensive and time-consuming. Opposition parties and survivors condemned the decision as a broken promise, arguing that funnelling money into the very systems that failed them is re-traumatizing and unjust.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Willow-Jean Prime (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: "Soul destroying" is how one survivor responded to the Government's shameful redress announcement on Friday. The final report from the royal commission was clear: survivors wanted an independent redress system. Funnelling more money into systems that have harmed them in the past is, without question, the wrong call.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Erica Stanford (National)
keyExchanges.quote: The advice that I had received around creating something new and complex—it would have taken an extraordinarily long period of time and would have been very expensive... The Government and Cabinet had to make a call on whether or not we went with something like that—highly complex, very expensive, would take a long time, and may not get us the outcomes that we expect.

topicSummaries.topic: First-Ever Withdrawals from NZ Super Fund Forecast for 2027
topicSummaries.content: Minister of Finance Nicola Willis announced that for the first time, withdrawals from the New Zealand Superannuation Fund are forecast to begin in the 2027-2028 fiscal year. This milestone, driven by a formula in the Act, signifies the fund is now large enough to begin covering some superannuation costs, which Willis said was occurring earlier than anticipated due to better-than-expected investment returns. She assured the House that the fund, currently valued at $80 billion, is projected to continue growing as returns are expected to outstrip withdrawals.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Nicola Willis (Minister of Finance)
keyExchanges.quote: In the short term, there will be some bouncing around between withdrawals and contributions, but from 2031 onwards, projections show that withdrawals from the super fund are expected in every year. Withdrawals help cover the costs of New Zealand's superannuation so taxpayers don't face the full cost each year.

topicSummaries.topic: $35M Boost for Customs to Fight Drug Smuggling
topicSummaries.content: The government will invest $35 million over four years to bolster the New Zealand Customs Service's efforts to combat drug smuggling and organised crime. Minister of Customs Casey Costello announced the funding will provide up to 60 additional roles, enhancing intelligence gathering, investigations, and supply chain security. The investment aims to make New Zealand a harder target for sophisticated criminal groups who are drawn by the high prices for illicit drugs in the country.

keyExchanges.speaker: Jamie Arbuckle (NZ First)
keyExchanges.quote: How will this additional investment be used?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Casey Costello (Minister of Customs)
keyExchanges.quote: This investment will provide Customs with up to 60 additional roles over the next four years, growing their capacity to gather intelligence and investigate and prosecute criminal actors. This additional capacity will support greater targeting of criminals involved in low quantity, high volume drug smuggling through channels like our mail and airports.

topicSummaries.topic: Ministers Face Scrutiny on Sanctions and Emergency Housing in Annual Review
topicSummaries.content: During the annual review debate for the Ministry of Social Development, ministers faced pointed questions about the social impact of government policies. Opposition MPs challenged the Minister for Social Development on whether increased benefit sanctions were contributing to rising food insecurity, particularly for children. The government defended its approach, stating sanctions are only for not fulfilling work obligations, not for failing to find a job. Questions were also raised about tightened 'gateway settings' for emergency housing and the potential impact on homelessness.

keyExchanges.speaker: Ricardo Menéndez March (Green)
keyExchanges.quote: Can I ask whether the Minister is aware as to whether there is a job available for every single person on the benefit, and, if not, what is the Minister doing to ensure that there is a job for every single person on the benefit?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Louise Upston (Minister for Social Development and Employment)
keyExchanges.quote: The sanctions are only if people don't fulfil their work obligations. They're not sanctioned if they can't find a job.

conclusion: The government stood firm on its fast-tracked legislative agenda on pay equity while facing intense criticism over its handling of redress for state care survivors, highlighting a day of deep ideological clashes over social and economic policy.
